displayed_text: Patient: I need a, either a stronger stool softener – Doctor: Or more. Patient: Or more. Doctor: So that. You’re takin’ Senokot. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Those two red pills? Patient: Right. Doctor: You take it twice a day. That doesn’t do the job? You take it three times a day. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: Okay? Morning, noon, and night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: Um um well let me see. (Laughing) Doctor: Sometimes we see your blood numbers for your liver and how they function, sometimes that gets a little bit screwed up. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that but some things we have to monitor. We always say anything with pills can affect your, your, you know your stomach and your bowels. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Doc -so that’s possible. You could get diarrhea or constipation – Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. I point that out out of all the list because that’s to me the most scary - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - if it were me. But you know point six is less – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah.

Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: He’ll probably tell you on that day – Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: When you’re likely to get… Do you have anything going on that you want us to work around then let them know at that time? Patient: That we probably can’t change. Doctor: Okay. Patient: The doctors you know. Doctor: Oh doctors, okay. Payments. Because then I was gonna say get that done before we start this whole process. Doctor: Okay so let me let them know okay and then you can leave but we’ll schedule the appointment with me and all that afterwards Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah.and probably Dr. C____ and I will see you same day like we did today. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? I love that color on you today.

Patient: Uh, it is still ain’t where I want it. You know? It’s like it’s, it be trying. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know? And, and, uh, sometimes it don’t, but, you know, I be feeling like it’s trying. Yeah. Doctor: Did you talk to Dr. D___ about it? Patient: No. I didn’t. No. I didn’t go. I just, I just said that I’m just going to be patient and just let things, you know, just keep doing what you’re telling me to do. And I still been taking the pills. Doctor: You’re taking the pills? Patient: Yes. Um hum. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: Well, so. Doctor: Alright. You know, we can, there are other options there for you. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Are you able to have an erection at all with the pills?

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or commonly known as Lupron is the brand name. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s other brands too, but that’s the brand we use. Family Member: Okay. Okay. And anything else? I’m asking all the questions. (Laughs) Patient: No. I just…. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I’m gonna have J___ come in so. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Thank you. Doctor: Okay, we have a communication study. Healthcare Professional: He’s already part of us. This is a survey for you to fill out.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And this what <___> I’m talking about so… Patient: Well I have an appointment with him next week. Doctor: The arms and hands are not something you can… Patient: No, no. Doctor: …get by easily without chuckles]]. Patient: So did you like Budapest? Doctor: Yes, it was interesting. I mean I had limited time, but it was… Patient: Yeah we did too. Doctor: I don’t think I would have ever thought of Budapest to visit if it weren’t for this meeting where I to be there. Patient: Yeah yeah right. Well we had been there. Doctor: It’s an incredible city. Oh my gosh! Like I never knew about, never thought about.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So okay. Real good. Family Member: Okay for M__ Patient: Anything else that I haven’t asked you?
DOC No. I’ll tell you what’s amazing. You look as good as you did even when we were having a bunch of these issues so that’s really a testament to you. That’s amazing. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: I mean you are, you know there’s a lot of stuff in there you got treated but you actually, you never looked bad and you look great, but you always look great so that makes me super happy. It really does. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: He goes outside. Doctor: Yes. He’s got a little color. (Laughs) Patient: If it wasn’t for this darn ankle I’d be… Doctor: I think you know what you need to do about that. You just got to ease up man. Patient: Yeah I do. Yeah. Thank you. God bless you. Family Member: Thank you.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: …that was hard to characterize. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That schmutz has sort of formalized more into you can call them a nodule, a mass… Patient: Mass. Doctor: …a thingy, a whatever it is, but it’s the cancer. Patient: Mass. Doctor: Which we know because you had a biopsy in the past which proved that to be so. Patient: Mhmm, mhmm. Doctor: And uh the bone is not that clear whether there’s anything in there. To me it doesn’t look like there’s any cancer in there. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: It looks like you have arthritis all the usual goodies that we’ve talked about, but mostly everything is here. Patient: You should have had uh, you should of had something here from where I had three broken ribs from a car wreck which I explained to the guy. You’re gonna see something there…

Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: Um. So, let me, uh, check in with I_ to see if she needs to follow with you, uh, because we’ll just stay on drug for now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I put the order in for the blood test. I need to just check to make sure that, with the holiday, that if I draw it, it’s not gonna get lost or be not usable because, uh, nobody’s here to work on it. Patient: Right. Doctor: They only run the test once a week. So, if they’re aware it’s coming today and they run it next Monday, then you’re golden. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, and then, we will set up when you need to come back, but I want you to take a look at these two, read them. We’ll know the AR-V7, hopefully within a week’s time. If that’s positive, then that would be this one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if it’s negative, it could be that one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or, if it was positive, you could still do that one. Um.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Your potassium two times a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: Prednisone one pill twice a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s what I have. Anything else you’re taking that I don’t know about? Patient: No. You’ve got it all. Doctor: So I’m going to put Bell’s palsy on here. You said it’s lopsided? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And you’ve had, not had any issues with depression in the past or anxiety? Patient: No. Doctor: Any acid reflux?

Patient: Right. That’s why – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I gave you that excel spreadsheet. Doctor: Yes. Patient: So there’s no question… Doctor: Not – not a Patient: …this is what J____ takes every single day. Doctor: Yes so then we know. Patient: And I’m very religious about it. Doctor: The other part now is sort of what do we do? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So let’s say we gather this information, we’re biopsying terrific, uh you know it’s all good for lab stuff, but what are we doing to actually treat it? There are several options. One, pills. Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Yeah. (mumbling to herself) Patient: Uh I didn’t know Lupron I I guess so. Doctor: Yeah. Mhmm. Now, do you want me to uh so what prescriptions do you need me to send? Patient: The… Doctor: The prednisone once a day. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And uh the Zofran and all that. Do you have enough? Patient: What’s the Zofran? Doctor: For the nausea? Patient: That’s the pill before you give me the other one right. The yellow ones I they they - I don’t know this… Doctor: I don’t think they’re yellow. Okay. Patient: Okay you know the pills you gave me before you gave me that the other ones, the crazy ones.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)

displayed_text: Family Member 1: Well I’m on blood thinners every day. Patient: So M___ is the next person to come in? Doctor: M____'s coming right in. Family Member 2: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - um we have not seen cases where that is curative. That is also another type of therapy that delays the progression of the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So so for example, if your primary goal was to delay hormone therapy for as long as possible, like if you really wanted at all cost to avoid hormone therapy - Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the one thing that we could consider would be referring you to a radiation oncologist that specializes in the type of radiation called stereotactic radio therapy, which is a very sort of focused - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - razor-sharp beam of radiation that targets one particular area and doesn’t really cause scattering of the x-rays to other areas. So it spares the normal tissues. Patient: Um Doctor: And we have people at this place that do that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um but I don’t want you to go into that therapy believing that this is also a potentially curative therapy. I think it could definitely cure the tumor in that one lymph node that we can see.

Patient: That gives me goose bumps. They never show up because my skin’s changed. Doctor: Yeah so here you go. (Laughs) Patient: Alright I’m gonna shut up and just let you keep talking. Doctor: Yeah well you know you need more chemo. That’s really what you need (laughs) Patient: I do? Doctor: You do. How ‘bout that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But your insurance today is not playing nice and it’s not letting us treat you today. Family Member: What? Doctor: Uh huh. Yes. K__’s yelling at somebody on the phone. United Health Care is not being very nice to you right now. And you know we put this in I don’t know how long ago right since the last time I’d seen you. They have hemmed and hawed and hemmed and hawed and given all sorts of problems. Patient: What do I need to do? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Can I do anything. I mean…
